issues.title: Do we need a way to encode PSKs?
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: This would, ideally, prohibit one from encoding PSKs as strings, since that tends to lead to less good PSKs. Think PSK = "bananas".

Maybe I could be preparing a 00 version of an I-D for this by monday.

issues.title: Document security assumptions
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: ... and describe attacks in all-honest (general) model.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @jhoyla can you take this?

comments.author: jhoyla
comments.body:
# Attacks on Properties under shared PSKs

TLS 1.3 tries to maintain 8 security properties in the handshake.
A naïve sharing of PSKs, even assuming only honest but curious participants know the key, can violate these properties.

## Establishing the same session keys
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.

1. Let the attacker compromise C.
2. A sends a `ClientHello` to  B. 
3. The attacker intercepts it, and passes it to C. 
4. C, under the direction of the attacker, sends a `ClientHello` to B, acting as A. 
5. B responds C thinking he is responding to A.
6. C responds to A.
7. A completes the handshake ostensibly with B, sending a `Finished` message.
8. C sends a `Finished` message to B.
9. B completes the handshake ostensibly with A.  

Although neither A nor B has been compromised, both have completed a session, ostensibly with each other, but have established different keys. 

## Secrecy of Session Keys
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C. 

1. Let A complete a PSK handshake with B without performing a fresh DHE.
2. C, an honest but curious agent, knows the PSK and can derive the session key.  

## Peer authentication
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.

1. A sends a `ClientHello` to B.
2. The attacker redirects the message to C. 
3. C responds to A.
4. A completes the handshake ostensibly with B, sending a `Finished` message. 
5. The attacker redirects the `Finished` message to C.
6. C completes the handshake ostensibly with A. 

## Uniqueness of session keys
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.

1. Let the attacker compromise C.
2. A sends a `ClientHello` with no key share to C.
3. The attacker repeats the `ClientHello` to B.
4. B responds to C.
5. The attacker repeats the response to A.
6. A completes the handshake ostensibly with C, sending a `Finished` message.
7. The attacker repeats the `Finished` message to B.
8. B completes the handshake ostensibly with C.

Although neither A nor B has been compromised they have each established a session with the attacker with the same key.

## Downgrade Protection
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.
Let A and B support strong and weak cipher suites, but let C support only weaker cipher suites. 

1. A sends a `ClientHello` to B.
2. The attacker redirects the message to C. 
3. C responds to A choosing a weak cipher suite.
4. A completes the handshake ostensibly with B, sending a `Finished` message with a weak cipher suite. 
5. The attacker redirects the `Finished` message to C.
6. C completes the handshake ostensibly with A. 


## Forward secret with respect to long-term keys
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.

1. Let A establish a PSK session with B, without a fresh DHE. 
2. Let the attacker record the session.
3. Let the attacker compromise C. 
 
The attacker can decrypt the recorded session, even though she compromised C _after_ A and B completed their session. 

## Key Compromise Impersonation (KCI) resistance
Let the group of peers who know the key be A, B, and C.

1. Let the attacker compromise A.
2. A sends a `ClientHello` to B.
3. The attacker intercepts the `ClientHello` and responds using the PSK learned from A.
4. A completes the handshake ostensibly with B, sending a `Finished` message.

Although B was never compromised the attacker is able to impersonate B to A. 


## Protection of endpoint identities
Although this has not seen any analysis, this appears to be secure, because even honest entities cannot distinguish each other.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Fixed in #10.

issues.title: Document stack implementations and APIs for external PSKs
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
# OpenSSL/BoringSSL

Applications configure callbacks that are invoked to select PSKs. These callbacks must provide the PSK identity (`char *`) and key (`unsigned char *) given a server PSK hint (`char *`).

- https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/man3/SSL_CTX_set_psk_client_callback.html

# mbedTLS

mbedTLS also treats PSKs as arbitrary byte arrays and character strings.

... from https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbedtls/blob/development/programs/ssl/ssl_client2.c:

```
    const char *psk;            /* the pre-shared key                       */
    const char *psk_identity;   /* the pre-shared key identity              */
```

```
mbedtls_ssl_conf_psk (mbedtls_ssl_config *conf, const unsigned char *psk, size_t psk_len, const unsigned char *psk_identity, size_t psk_identity_len)
```

- https://tls.mbed.org/api/ssl_8h.html
- https://tls.mbed.org/api/ssl_8h.html#a1e185199e3ff613bdd1c8231a19e24fc

# gnuTLS

Applications specify a "username" (as the PSK identity) and a raw PSK. 

- https://www.gnutls.org/manual/html_node/Authentication-using-PSK.html
- http://man7.org/linux/man-pages/man3/gnutls_psk_set_client_credentials.3.html

# wolfSSL

Callback style (with identical key and identity types) similar to OpenSSL. There is no minimum length enforced for the PSK.

- https://www.wolfssl.com/using-pre-shared-keys-psk-with-wolfssl-2/
- https://github.com/wolfSSL/wolfssl-examples/blob/master/psk/client-psk-nonblocking.c

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Fixed in #4.

issues.title: Expand stack behavior section
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
> I think we should also discuss what kind of matching is done on the PSK identity. For example, RFC 7925 says: "For use with this profile, the PSK identities SHOULD NOT assume a structured format (such as domain names, distinguished names, or IP addresses), and a byte-by-byte comparison operation MUST be used by the server for any operation related to the PSK identity."

> Similarly, RFC 4279 in Section 5.1 describes the UTF-8 encoding of identities to improve interoperability for those cases where the identity is configured by a human using some management interface.

> If in TLS 1.3, the identity is only used as a hint for looking up the correct PSK in the database, then this would be a significant departure from what was the norm previously. Highlighting this in our document would make sense.

> The current text also says 'These callbacks must provide the PSK identity (as a character string)'. But the openssl s_server and s_client seem to work without providing PSK identities and use the default character string 'Client_identity' as the psk_identity.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s do you want to take a stab at this?

comments.body: Fixed in #10.

issues.title: Recommendation text
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
1. Start with the general recommendation and invariant: Identities should be unique across all nodes, roles, and keys. 
2. For each use case, how a part of the invariant is violated and leads to one of the known attacks.

issues.title: Guidance on PSK and identifier structure
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
- PSKs: Minimum length? Minimum derivation entropy?
- Identifiers: Can it be any length? Maybe it just needs to be unique to the application?

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body: Does the PSK identity need to have entropy? Can't it be user configurable? EAP identities are generally a NAI (RFC 7542). They look like an email address and are in many cases configured by the user through a GUI.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Discussed on the call -- I don't think we can say anything meaningful here beyond "it needs to make sense to the application." @ms-s, can you please propose text?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Let's fold this into #17!

issues.title: Russ's feedback
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Section 3.1.1: The text says:

   3.  C responds with to A.

I think that C responds with a ServerHello to A.


Section 3.1.2:  The text says:

   1.  A sends a ClientHello to B, without including a key share.

It would be helpful to say "without including a key share extension."


Section 3.1.3: I think a bit more explanation is needed here.  Nonces can make the keys different, why doesn't the nonce from the uncompromised party help in this example?


Section 4: I would like to see a bit more context here.  I agree with the recommendations for the intended environment, but they are overkill in the environment suggested by draft-ietf-tls-tls13-cert-with-extern-psk.  In fact, they are overkill if (EC)DH is combined with the PSK at all.  So, maybe we just need to say that the PSK is not combined with a pairwise key that these rules apply.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Fixed by #20.

issues.title: Clarify identity mismatch behavior
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
What should servers do if they get an identity which doesn't match a known key? Do they send an alert or try any PSK? (OpenSSL does the latter, it seems.)

   unknown_psk_identity:  Sent by servers when PSK key establishment is
      desired but no acceptable PSK identity is provided by the client.
      Sending this alert is OPTIONAL; servers MAY instead choose to send
      a "decrypt_error" alert to merely indicate an invalid PSK
      identity.

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body:
Currently, any identity is accepted as long as a matching PSK is found. For example:
openssl s_server -accept 4433 -psk 1a2b3c4d -nocert -tls1_3 -psk_identity 'test' -trace and
openssl s_client -connect 127.0.0.1:4433 -psk 1a2b3c4d -sess_out sesion -tls1_3 -psk_identity 'wewe' -trace

results in successful connection even though psk_identity at server 'test' does not match psk_identity at client 'wewe'.

Server should either send a fatal "decrypt_error" alert or then "unknown_psk_identity" alert.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: We should also clarify badness that comes from identity collisions. @ms-s, can you please take this?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closing in favor of #22.

issues.title: Discuss resumption vs external PSK usage
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Starter text from @upros!

```
### External PSK versus Resumption PSK Handling

  [[TODO: this section needs TLS stack implementers guidance]]

  On receipt of a `ClientHello` containing  PSK identity, OpenSSL appears to callback to the application first in order to allow the application to check if the PSK is an externally provisioned PSK: https://github.com/openssl/openssl/blob/master/ssl/statem/extensions_srvr.c#L1093. If the application cannot find the external PSK idenitty in its external cache, the TLS stack will then check its resumption cache. We need to document TLS stack vs. application implementers guidance about the sequencing of handling of External vs. Resumption PSKs.
```

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @upros can you please take this?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Ping @upros!

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closed by #32.

issues.title: Describe PSK variant security properties
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Discuss the different variants:

1. High entropy PSK+DH
2. High entropy PSK-only
3. Low PSK with strong (balanced) PAKE

... and their security properties.

For encodings, mention RFC1751 and Bjorn's draft.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
Proposed text:

If a high entropy PSK is used, then PSK-only key establishment modes
are secure against both active and passive attack, but will not enjoy
forward security. Forward security may be achieved by using a PSK-DH
mode.

If a low entropy PSK is used, then PSK-only key establishment modes
are subject to passive exhaustive search passive attacks which
will reveal the traffic keys. PSK-DH modes are subject to active
attacks in which the attacker impersonates one side. The exhaustive
search phase of these attacks can be mounted offline if the attacker
captures a single handshake using the PSK, but those attacks will
not lead to compromise of the traffic keys for that connection
because those also depend on the DH exhange. Low entropy keys
are only secure against active attack if a PAKE is used with TLS.

issues.title: Update PSK usage guidance text
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
Summary: use a high-entropy PSK with DH, otherwise, with a low-entropy PSK, use a PAKE. 

Reference appendix with security properties from @ekr.

issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: cc @ms-s

issues.title: Address Verisign's review
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/bzLaqkObq5p-KYHb4m7y263Z_aA/

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
Rephrase requirement 1 as:

> "If only low-entropy keys are available, then key establishment 
> mechanisms such as Password Authenticated Key Exchange (PAKE) that 
> mitigate the risk of offline dictionary attacks MUST be employed.  Note 
> that these mechanisms do not necessarily follow the same architecture 
> as the ordinary process for incorporating EPSKs described in this 
> draft."

Rephrase requirement 2 as:

> "Unless other accommodations are made, each PSK MUST be restricted in 
> its use to at most two logical nodes:  one logical node in a TLS client 
> role and one logical node in a TLS server role.  (The two logical nodes 
> MAY be the same, in different roles.)  Two acceptable accommodations 
> are described in [draft-ietf-tls-external-psk-importer]:  exchanging 
> client and server identifiers  over the TLS connection after the 
> handshake; and incorporating identifiers  for both the client and the 
> server into the context string for an EPSK importer."

Add some missing definitions, likely in a separate definitions section.

> Related to this, "logical node" should be defined somewhere, e.g., "For 
> purposes of this document, a logical node is a computing presence that 
> other parties can interact with via the TLS protocol.  A logical node 
> could potentially be realized with multiple physical instances 
> operating under common administrative control, e.g., a server farm."  
> Alternatively, the term "endpoint," which is used elsewhere in this 
> document, could be used here as well (perhaps also avoiding the single 
> use of "agent").

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Addressed by #34.

issues.title: PSK privacy implications
issues.author: ms-s
issues.body:
Carrick Bartle in her review writes:
>  Applications should take precautions when using external PSKs to mitigate these risks.
What sort of precautions should they take?

Do we want to make any recommendations. Jim Schaad provided some recommendation on the mailing list:
https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/CJ0YrVI9Gy7LFE032xytwrz7mmo/ 

[JLS] There are going to be three different cases for external PSK identities: The identity if factory provisioned and carried in a file to the server,  the identity is factory provisioned and read by the user from the device, and it is hand chosen.  The first two cases can definitely be randomized.  I don’t know that having a minimum length makes any difference.  This is not exactly a cryptographic property.  Another thing that might be done would be analogous to the PSK importer document and apply a one way hash from the typed in value to the value that is sent over the wire so on the wire it is just a random set of bytes.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: nit: s/his/her :-)

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body:
Isn't there a fourth case JLS didn't mention, namely some other out-of-band provisioning over a secure connection? In that case, a new PSK could be provisioned after each use. (This might seem silly, but I've seen two separate use-cases for this.)

Alternatively, in any of those cases, is it feasible to do some sort of ratcheting? (This is sort of expanding on the last sentence in JLS's paragraph.)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Hmm, @cbartle891, there is. I'm wary about writing down any sort of recommendation here, though, as they would probably require analysis. (In contrast to the recommendations about PSK length, for which we understand the requirements quite well, I don't think we have a good way to reason about techniques to deal with external PSK privacy... yet.)

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body:
In that case, I'm in favor of deleting this line: "Applications should take precautions when using external PSKs to mitigate these risks." Mentioning precautions we don't describe is less helpful than not mentioning them at all (since it's confusing).

Even better though would be to state that such precautions are an open problem that require analysis.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Yep, that seems reasonable to me!

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: @cbartle891 - At this point I would implement the - lets roll over the PSK on each use into the case of issuing tokens and just void the PSK (and token) on the first usage.

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: @chris-wood What type of analysis are you looking for on this?  It hardly needs to have a cryptographic analysis since this is not a cryptographic property.   Are you looking for some analysis that the input and output cannot be correlated?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> @chris-wood What type of analysis are you looking for on this? It hardly needs to have a cryptographic analysis since this is not a cryptographic property. Are you looking for some analysis that the input and output cannot be correlated?

Minimally, yes.

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: While it may be odd - you could ask the PSK importer document to do this and just note the privacy problem here.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @jimsch would you mind proposing text (preferably for this document)?

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: @jimsch What sort of tokens are you referring to?

comments.author: jimsch
comments.body: @cbartle891 In this case the token should be ticket.  I have token on the brain because that is what we use for a similar idea in ACE.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s @cbartle891, do you think this issue is resolved?

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: Yep!

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Excellent -- closing as is!

issues.title: Watson's review
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
From [Watson's feedback on the list](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/MKBcycX3Qbz-_XSTNfPFobWTxV0/):

> In particular  "SHOULD be combined with a DH exchange for forward
> secrecy." I would like to see rephrased to make clear that this is
> about the TLS PSK Key Exchange Mode. It wasn't immediately clear to me
> on first read, especially given the next sentence is (maybe) about key
> establishment outside of TLS.

Good suggestion. Let's clarify!

> "If only low-entropy keys are available, then key establishment
> mechanisms such as Password Authenticated Key Exchange (PAKE) that
> mitigate the risk of offline dictionary attacks SHOULD be employed".
> I have some questions about the meaning of this sentence. If it's
> about potential future additions to TLS ciphersuites, then it should
> be more clear that this doesn't currently exist and will in the
> future.  If it's about designing an ad-hoc key distribution mechanism
> to be run one time ahead of PSK TLS, then I think we should say so
> more clearly and provide guidance on how to do this and think through
> the implications.

My interpretation was that it speaks of the future :-) We can clarify this. 

> Section 7.1.1. While it's a good idea to compare byte by byte, humans
> entering PSK identifiers may run into trouble due to all the ways
> visually identical strings may not actually be identical. It might be
> worth calling this out as a consideration.

That seems reasonable. I'll propose text.

issues.title: Why use both certificates and a PSK on the same connection?
issues.author: cbartle891
issues.body:
(This question is copied from my email.)

The draft states: "To perform rare system specific operations that require a higher security level, the central server can request resource-intensive client authentication with the usage of a certificate after successfully establishing the connection with a PSK."

If you're going to authenticate with a cert, why bother preceding that 
with an authentication with a PSK?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s can you please take this?

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body:
#45  and this refer to the same use-case and can be merged.

This use-case is described in the publication by Akhmetzyanova et al. https://eprint.iacr.org/2019/421.pdf. See section 4. In the scenario described by the authors, resource-constrained IoT devices are TLS clients. The PSK is used for authenticating the central server and client membership of the system. Only for rare device-specific operations requiring a higher-security level (such as device firmware update), the server can request resource-intensive client authentication with certificates after successfully establishing the connection with PSK. This deployment may seem somewhat artificial but it was necessary 
in the paper to explain the possible attack scenarios.

Also answered on the mailing list here: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/jdTQu9O-3WS2efav_ciI1uKf9mQ/

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: That rephrases the content in the draft; I guess what I'm asking for is a brief explanation as to why authenticating the client with a certificate is necessary to circumvent those attack scenarios.

issues.title: Why do all IoT clients on a system need the same PSK?
issues.author: cbartle891
issues.body:
(This question is copied from my email.)

The draft states: "In this use-case, resource-constrained IoT devices act as TLS clients and share the same PSK. The devices use this PSK for quickly establishing connections with a central server. Such a scheme ensures that the client IoT devices are legitimate members of the system."

If the IoT devices only talk to a central server and not each other, why do they all need the same PSK? That doesn't seem like a good idea, given that the clients can then impersonate each other and listen in on each other's traffic.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s can you please take this?

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: The explanation in https://github.com/tlswg/external-psk-design-team/issues/44 doesn't address why it's okay or desirable for all the clients to have the same PSK. The clients are constrained, being IoT devices, but the server isn't, and presumably can handle n PSKs for n clients.

comments.author: jhoyla
comments.body:
The best argument I can come up with for why a server might want all devices to have the same key is if there are many devices and a high rate of turnover. Rather than trying to keep track of rapidly changing list of keys, perhaps it is easier to just use a single key, especially if there is a high penalty if a device is unable to connect.
Further, if the devices have a way of upgrading to a more secure connection when necessary, then the central server may not care if devices can impersonate one another.
Not sure it's very convincing, but perhaps at least plausible?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
I don't think we need to rationalize the use case. The point of this section is to *document* known use cases, not *justify* them, and to provide recommendations for using PSKs in such circumstances. 

@cbartle891: I'm not sure what action you're looking for here. Justification is out of scope, I think.

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: You can close this then, since this relates to the discussion elsewhere about justification.

issues.title: Further detail needed on distributing pair-wise keys
issues.author: cbartle891
issues.body:
(Also adding this question from the email.)

The draft states: "PSK provisioning systems are often constrained in application-specific ways. For example, although one goal of provisioning is to ensure that each pair of nodes has a unique key pair, some systems do not want to distribute pair-wise shared keys to achieve this."

Why wouldn't a system want to distribute pair-wise keys? What application-specific constraint would warrant that? (I'm imagining, for instance, that maybe that would overload the network or something, but the reason should probably be explained rather than left to the imagination.)

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s can you please take this?

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body:
This text is based on the input from Björn Haase. Essentially, he indicated that some industrial control deployments do not want to have O(n^2) keys for a system with n nodes, but they do want to minimize sharing. I am fine with changing it to "might not want to" or removing this constraint completely. 

Also answered on the mailing list here: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/tls/jdTQu9O-3WS2efav_ciI1uKf9mQ/

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: Ah, that seems like an important point to mention. It makes sense that provisioning O(n^2) keys would be overburdensome on a system, but if it doesn't, there are security trade-offs, right?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body:
> Ah, that seems like an important point to mention. It makes sense that provisioning O(n^2) keys would be overburdensome on a system, but if it doesn't, there are security trade-offs, right?

Yep. @cbartle891: what sort of change are you looking for here?

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: @jhoyla's change works for me.

issues.title: Jim's review
issues.author: chris-wood
issues.body:
* In section 4 there is a statement that switching the roles of servers
which use PSKs will lead to weakening of security properties.  As this is a
common scenario today in situations where you are doing server-to-server
communication, it would be useful to discuss just how and how much this
weakening occurs.  This was a complete surprise to me and I don't know if it
was supposed to be one.  Are there mitigations that can be made?

* In section 7, The first sentence does not read, also It seems a bit
difficult to have a MUST in there when most of the items below are SHOULDs.
That seems to be a dissonance.

* Section 7.1.1 - The idea of having domain name suffixes on PSKs seems to
me to be a bad idea as this would seem to lower privacy levels.

* Section 7.1.2 - There seem to me to be three different places where
collisions will occur.  The importer function could get a collision, there
could be collisions with pre-TLS 1.2 external identifiers and there could be
collision with resumption keys.  There has been a huge discussion about this
in the EMU group and I don't find the text here to be sensible in term of
whether this is or is not a problem.

* Section 7.1.2 - One of the things that I kept meaning to get to and just
haven't done so yet, is dealing with the question of can the TLS Key binders
in the handshake to distinguish between multiple keys that happen to have
the same identity.  Perhaps you should look to see if this does work and if
it is safe.

issues.title: The "ordinary process" of incorporating external PSKs
issues.author: cbartle891
issues.body:
(This question is copied from my email with greater context from the draft.)

Section 7.1 is the following:

"Each PSK SHOULD be derived from at least 128 bits of entropy, MUST be at least 128 bits long, and SHOULD be combined with a DH exchange for forward secrecy. As discussed in Section 4, low entropy PSKs, i.e., those derived from less than 128 bits of entropy, are subject to attack and SHOULD be avoided. If only low-entropy keys are available, then key establishment mechanisms such as Password Authenticated Key Exchange (PAKE) that mitigate the risk of offline dictionary attacks SHOULD be employed. Note that these mechanisms do not necessarily follow the same architecture as the ordinary process for incorporating EPSKs described in this draft."

Where was the ordinary process for incorporating EPSKs described? Is "incorporating" a PSK the same as "provisioning" one? If so, several ways were described. What's the problem with these mechanisms (e.g. PAKE) having a different architecture from these ordinary processes? Are they not compatible?

comments.author: jhoyla
comments.body:
Perhaps this refers to the process in I-D.ietf-tls-external-psk-importer, which takes a provisioned PSK and performs a transformation on it to ensure that it is unique? That can then be incorporated into the key schedule. 
This is different from the PAKE process, which doesn't pass through the ePSK importer mechanism. 
Not sure if that was the original intention, but if so we should write clarifying text.

issues.title: PSK Security Properties Incomplete
issues.author: jhoyla
issues.body:
The sentence "TLS 1.3 tries to maintain the following seven security properties:" leaves out the eighth property, "Protection of Endpoint Identities". 
The reason it was left out is (presumably) because RFC explicitly calls out protection of certificates, but in Section 5 we discuss the privacy properties of PSKs, so it seems appropriate to mention it here, even if to say that it doesn't apply directly.
See #36.

comments.author: jhoyla
comments.body: We also mention "Protection of Endpoint Identities" in Section 3.1 which becomes something of a non-sequitur.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I don't see this sentence in the document, so I'm considering this overcome by events! Please re-open (and send a PR) if you think it's not addressed.

issues.title: replace master
issues.author: seanturner
issues.body:
s7 includes the following and in light of 8446bis we should probable replace "master":

    4.  Where possible the master PSK (that which is fed into the
        importer) SHOULD be deleted after the imported keys have been
        generated.  This protects an attacker from bootstrapping a
        compromise of one node into the ability to attack connections
        between any node; otherwise the attacker can recover the master
        key and then re-run the importer itself.

issues.title: Group PSKs
issues.author: ms-s
issues.body:
The draft currently says "It is NOT RECOMMENDED to share the same PSK between more than one client and server."

John says: group PSK violates both “peer authentication” and “downgrade protection property”. It also violates “secrecy of the session keys”. Two-party PSK already does not provide “Key Compromise Impersonation (KCI) resistance” and “Protection of endpoint identities” and psk_key does not provide “Forward secret with respect to long-term keys”. So when psk_ke is used in a group, the only property left is “Uniqueness of the session keys”...I am skeptical to introduce this new group PSK mode in an informal guidance document. If group PSK should be allowed, it should be more clearly declared as a new mode of TLS 1.3 and the security properties given and not given should be more clearly stated.

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body: I guess John thinks NOT RECOMMENDED is not sufficient and we should stronger language like SHALL NOT.

issues.title: TLS 1.3 vs 1.2 API
issues.author: ms-s
issues.body:
The draft says “OpenSSL and BoringSSL: Applications specify support for external PSKs via distinct ciphersuites.”

John wrote: I assume this is not the case for TLS 1.3 as the cipher suites in TLS 1.3 are independent of the authentication.

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body: I guess it would help to clarify. In my opinion, we should only look at APIs of TLS 1.3.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I fixed this directly on main.

issues.title: Adding security weaknesses of two party PSK
issues.author: ms-s
issues.body:
John wrote: There also several weaknesses/limitation that are hinted at in RFC 8446 which apply for two-party PSK authenticated connections. As this is a guidance document for all uses of external PSK, I think this document should bring up and expand upon:

-	Key Compromise Impersonation (KCI) resistance 
-	Protection of endpoint identities  
-	Forward secret with respect to long-term keys (psk_ke only) 

An additional security property given by signature authentication but not psk authentication is non-repudiation. As stated by Wikipedia “By this property, an entity that has signed some information cannot at a later time deny having signed it.”

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body: This is a fair comment and I don't see any reason not to add these

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: @ms-s, can you please send a PR?

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: Closing as resolved (by #65).

pulls.title: Add stack interface section.
pulls.author: chris-wood
pulls.body:
First cut at #4.

cc @ms-s

comments.author: ms-s
comments.body:
Thanks a lot. This looks good to start with.

I think we should also discuss what kind of matching is done on the PSK identity. For example, RFC 7925 says: "For use with this profile, the PSK identities SHOULD NOT assume a structured format (such as domain names, distinguished names, or IP addresses), and a byte-by-byte comparison operation MUST be used by the server for any operation related to the PSK identity."

Similarly, RFC 4279 in Section 5.1 describes the UTF-8 encoding of identities to improve interoperability for those cases where the identity is configured by a human using some management interface. 

If in TLS 1.3, the identity is only used as a hint for looking up the correct PSK in the database, then this would be a significant departure from what was the norm previously. Highlighting this in our document would make sense.

The current text also says 'These callbacks must provide the PSK identity (as a character string)'. But the openssl s_server and s_client seem to work without providing PSK identities and use the default character string 'Client_identity' as the psk_identity.

comments.author: chris-wood
comments.body: I'll merge and will remove it for now. Owen can add it when he gets around to his PR.
This bullet is not something that can "vary depending on the deployment." Can we just move this to its own paragraph below the list, or merge with the first paragraph in this section?
The second and third sentences in this bullet seem like too much information for the requirement. Can we please revert to the previous text?
This is redundant with the text in I-D.ietf-tls-external-psk-importer. Since item (3) already recommends using it, I think we should remove this entire bullet.
It's really hard for me to pull out the requirement from this paragraph. Can we please simplify it, or remove it altogether?
This feels like a bit of a non-sequitur. We're not using PSK importers to change the hash-function, we using them to make the keys distinct.
Maybe we should drop a link to RFC 4122 (UUID) here? Can you create stable ID from a UUID? Do we need to consider access to clock?
This was done based on feedback from Björn. Feel free to move around this text to some other suitable place in the document. But I agree with Björn that this is definitely worth highlighting.
Added a reference to RFC 4122. Thanks for the suggestion.
That's correct. Moved this above the bullet list.

This is a guidance document so it is worth pointing out different ways of doing things. I added a reference to UUID (RFC 4122) based on feedback from Jonathan. I understand that you want to keep the recommendations concise. So moved this text to the security considerations.

It is quite simple. We don't recommend sharing PSKs among many nodes. If someone's use case still wants that, then they should use external PSK importers. However, that by itself is not enough. Nodes should know the other end points identifier to prevent rerouting of attacks. And of course, endpoints that know the PSK can always impersonate.
This is a lot of text to simply say, "If you share PSKs, make sure you also include some other form of unique identifier." Can we please simplify it?
Please revert deleting this text!
This paragraph does not add information. Please remove it.

I am really sorry for the accidental deletion. Reverted.

Should be fixed.
Should be fixed now!
I have shortened the security considerations section somewhat. We can further shorten it if others also feel the same way.
No problem!
This whole section section seems to have different formatting. I'd prefer we just revert this entirely. (That is, break lines at ~80-120 columns, give or take.) I can do that after we merge though.
Yes. My editor doesn't add line breaks and I seem to like it. I guess it is best if you do it after the merge.

pulls.title: Move comment about password guidance to the introduction.
pulls.author: cbartle891
pulls.body:
The comment about how there are no guidelines about PSKs like there are about generating passwords seemed like a statement of the motivation for this draft, so I moved it to the introduction.

(I was going to add a reference for the statement, but I couldn't figure out how to get the citation to compile correctly. This was the document I was going to cite, in case you think it needs it: https://pages.nist.gov/800-63-3/sp800-63b.html.)

comments.body:
```suggestion
There are many resources that provide guidance for password generation and verification aimed towards improving security. 
However, there is no such equivalent for external Pre-Shared Keys (PSKs) in TLS. This document aims to reduce
that gap. It lists TLS security properties provided by PSKs under certain assumptions and demonstrates
how violations of these assumptions lead to attacks. This document also discusses PSK use
cases, provisioning processes, and TLS stack implementation support in the context of these
assumptions. It provides advice for applications in various use cases to help meet these
assumptions.
```

pulls.title: Add brief rationale for recommendation of importers.
pulls.author: cbartle891

comments.body:
```suggestion
when configuring PSKs for a client-server pair. Importers make provisioning
external PSKs easier and less error prone by deriving a unique, imported PSK from the 
external PSK for each key derivation function a node supports. See the Security Considerations
in {{!I-D.ietf-tls-external-psk-importer}} for more information.
```

pulls.title: Address Carrick's review.
pulls.author: jhoyla
pulls.body: Closes #44, #45, and #47.

comments.author: jhoyla
comments.body: @cbartle891 does this address your (other) comments?

comments.author: cbartle891
comments.body: I think this adds really helpful context to what would otherwise be confusing on its own, thanks.

"full security" seems too vague. I'd recommend reverting this change, as I don't think it adds much and isn't consistent with the other items in this list. (This bullet item is identifying IoT as a use case, not explaining all the ways in which IoT systems may use PSKs, and why those certain ways are good or bad or whatever.)

```suggestion
- Internet of Things (IoT) and devices with limited computational capabilities. Many PSK provisioning examples are possible in this use-case. For example, in a given setting, IoT devices may all share the same PSK and use it to communicate with a central server (one key for n devices), have their own key for communicating with a central server (n keys for n devices), or have pairwise keys for communicating with each other (n^2 keys for n devices). 

The exact provisioning process depends on the system requirements and threat model. Generally, use of 
a single PSK shared between more than one node is not recommended, even if other accommodations 
are made, such as client certificate authentication after PSK-based connection establishment. 
See {{recommendations}}.
```

Unrelated to your change, but I'd also suggest rewriting this item:

```suggestion
- Group chats. In this use-case, group participants may be provisioned an external PSK out-of-band for establishing authenticated connections with other members of the group.
```
